They were not treated well. There are numerous memoirs written by prisoners available on the web (see http://www.csa-dixie.com/csa/prisoners/t28.htm). They tell of purposeful starvation of prisoners to punish the Confederacy (they had no food to give their prisoners) and save money (the commandant at Rock Island wrote letters in which he is proud of saving money by not feeding Confederate prisoners, letting them starve to death) and sentries who randomly shot helpless prisoners to death when they were asleep in their bunks, sitting in doorways and going to the sinks at night when they were ill.  The Union should be ashamed. Even your local newspapers protested the terrible treatment of prisoners. When my great-grandfather arrived, one of the first prisoners there, the barracks were not finished. Confederate prisoners were housed in barracks with huge cracks between the boards in the walls. They wore very worn clothing not suitable to northern winters and were not allowed to keep their blankets. Don't make it sound like they had creature comforts. They did not. You have access to the records and should not perpetuate the lie that it was a humane place.

Thank you to everyone for your participation in our Island-wide Electronic Town Hall. We look forward to the next quarterly Town Hall. Between now and then, please feel free to ask the Commander questions with the Ask the Garrison Commander button located on our Garrison page at www.usagria.army.mil. We make every effort to reply within 24 hours.

Good evening -- I am Col. Elmer Speights, Jr., commander of U.S. Army Garrison Rock Island Arsenal. Welcome to the Rock Island Arsenal's Island-wide Electronic Town Hall. I am here with my staff to address your questions. We'll make every effort to answer, here and now, in real time. For more complex responses, or those requiring research, we may ask if we can find an answer and get back to you. We do ask that all questions concern the Arsenal and its operations, and that all participants conduct themselves as adults and good neighbors. Thanks for participating and being a good neighbor of Rock Island Arsenal. Let's begin.

With parking having and still being an issue on the Arsenal, has a parking deck been concidered?  The parking lot by building 90 would be well suited for it as there is always an influx of students at DAU taking away parking for those of us in building 68 and would oliviate parking on the street and other illigal parking.  Another option would be the green area across from building 68 where the brick house is located.

Last year a new wheelchair ramp was installed on the far NW door of building 102.  Unfortunately  it can’t be used by those needing to enter the building at that door because it is locked. Around the  corner at the other 102 door on the west side there is no ramp and a scanner that doesn’t work. Why is that? Also it would be helpful for there to be a paved sidewalk from the bottom of those stairs to the street for getting to the street especially in the winter.
I have been on the Arsenal for three years now and I must say in the last two years I have seen a great deal of improvement, thanks to the Garrison Commander.

There is a big issue of parking for contractors responding to priority calls. It seems security picks and chooses when and where they are going to ticket. I understand parking in a fire lane is against the rules but to load and unload material should be allowed at some point. There are not enough spots around the buildings and the ones that are always have vehicles in them that are parking longer than the 2 hour regulation

When will the installation go to card readers as with many other installations around the country, increasing the traffic through put at gates for arsenal workers while having guards for Arsenal visitor requiring more time and attendance.

On the Davenport Gate:  Some Fridays we will have two guys working the gate and both are taking CAC Cards.  EXCELLENT! While this postcard is from 1935, the graphic in it would be from further back. Here's some history of the Clock Tower Building: This fine old building is on the National Register of Historic Places and has been the home of the Rock Island District of the Corps of Engineers since 1934. The history of the Clock Tower Building, which stands at the western tip of Arsenal Island, reaches all the way back to the Civil War. Congress, by the Act of July 11, 1862, established three new arsenals: at Columbus, Ohio, Indianapolis, Ind., and on the Government-owned Island of Rock Island in the Mississippi River. At each site, Congress authorized the construction of one storehouse. Storehouse A, as the Clock Tower Building was originally known, became the first building of the new Rock Island Arsenal. On April 20, 1864, the cornerstone was laid. In 1931, a Rock Island District field construction office moved into the first floor of the Clock Tower Building to supervise the first work on the project, the construction of Locks and Dam 15, a few hundred feet away. Since Storehouse A had never been intended for anything but storage, much renovation was necessary. There were no permanent partitions, no water, and no passenger elevator. In a flurry of activity, often around the clock, in 1934, the District Engineer, Col. R. A. Wheeler, officially moved his office to the Clock Tower Building and a surrounding 6.9 acre triangle of land was transferred from the Ordnance Department to the Corps of Engineers.

Good evening -- I am Col. Elmer Speights Jr., commander of the U.S. Army Garrison, Rock Island Arsenal. Welcome to the Rock Island Arsenal's Island-wide Electronic Townhall. I am here with my staff to address your questions. We'll make every effort to answer, here and now, in real time. For more complex responses, or those requiring research, we may ask if we can find an answer and get back to you. We do ask that all questions concern the Arsenal and its operations, and that all participants conduct themselves as adults and good neighbors. Thanks for participating and being a good neighbor of Rock Island Arsenal. Let's begin.

Thank you to everyone for your participation in our Island-wide Electronic Townhall. For any questions that we are following up on we will be posting those responses in coming days. We look forward to the next townhall to be conducted quarterly, and for special events, as this one has been a success. Between now and then, please feel free to ask the Commander questions with the Ask the Garrison Commander button. We attempt to reply within 24 hours.

Sir, I have a couple question regarding the new locality pay for our area.  Being a NG soldier, I found it strange that the Rock Island area had such a high BAH rate compared to other areas while the locality for RIA was classified as rest of United States.  With the new locality rate hopefully taking affect January of 2016, is there any light you can shed on the process or any insight as to what we can expect?

The following question/statement was submitted for the Town Hall via Interactive Customer Evaluation (ICE):

✂ Rock Island Arsenal is a very small island. The grass on Rock Island is also very small and little to it. I see NO REASON that mowers are out there every day cutting the grass at 0730. I can fully and completely understand it taking a day.I can even see and understand the need for breaks with the heat so it can be completed in a day; however, the fact that they are out there most each and every day for the amount of grass is a bit overboard. Some people DO LIVE ON ISLAND and most cut our own lawn and know the amount of time it should take especially  since they have a riding lawn mower. This is very nerve wrecking when a person is trying to SLEEP. Some have to be up late due to work, school etc and this VERY disturbing.

Background on ICE: ICE allows DoD customers to rate products and services provided by DoD offices and facilities worldwide. Your comment card ratings are used to improve the products and services available to you. http://go.usa.gov/36cPT

Branding is great... but did we do ourselves any favors by placing the Army logo on the water tower - AT THE EXPENSE OF the longstanding and customary American practice of naming the community on the tower? Most cities and towns have logos, but virtually every tower in every town in the USA has the name of the place proudly announcing its existence for miles around.  Both the logo and the name an easily COEXIST on the tower - and there is ample precedent for Army water towers bearing the name of the installation. It's called unit esprit... same logic that dictates we wear unit patches AND a US Army tape on our uniforms.

My question pertains to water quality. It seems that much of the time the water has a bad taste and smell to it. We cook, drink and bathe in this water.  Is the water we are using meeting the quality standards and what has been done ensure that we do not have any water issues(modernization project)?

First off, I am seeing a lot of new faces at the Guard Gates and the ones I have encountered are doing an excellent job.  The Guards and Police on this installation do not get enough credit for a job well done.  I have a comment and a request.  First, the Comment.  I would like all employees on this installation to treat the guards and our police better.  They have some of the most difficult jobs on this installation and people take them for granted.  If you see this, remind yourself of what they do to protect our installation and thank them for their dedication and service.  Most, if not all our former military and fought for our nation to protect us.  Just because their uniform is different doesn't make them any less dedicated to protect us and ensure our safety.  Second, Request.  I drive on base between 7 and 7:15 each day and usually go through the golf course.  I would really like to see more speed traps/patrols during this time.  There are so many soldiers doing PT at this time, and everyone seems to ignore the signs to reduce speeds to 10 mph.  I fear that someone is going to get hurt.

With the resurfacing of the parking lots, why are there no concrete motorcycle parking spots in the lots except the lot across from First Army?   Buildings 102-104 have several that drive motorcycles.  I have come out after work to see my kickstand sunk 1" into the asphalt.

How about flattening the 'whopp-di-doos' in the pavement on northbound Sylvan Dr (skirting the west fence line of JMTC)  just as it approaches the traffic light at Rodman. I bottomed out going only 15 mph, making a right turn on to Rodman.

My question is regarding getting a security pass.  The information the garrison has put out states that the physical security division issues badges from 600 am until 340 pm.  Why then is the office closed every day for lunch from 1100 am until 1200 pm?  I came over the other week to get some information on getting a security pass, but was told to come back after 1200 pm because the office was closed for lunch.  When I asked if someone else could help me I was told no, but I saw several other employees sitting at their desk.  I also witnessed several others get turned away by the same individual because he was at lunch, but he was sitting at his desk.  I understand that people need a lunch break, but why can't the physical security division alternate their employees lunches, so the office remains open during the posted hours of operation?  If not can you please put out to the public that the office is closed from 1100 am until 1200 pm for lunch, so people don't waste their time coming there to get a badge.

When 2nd & 3rd streets were improved where they meet North Ave, the sidewalks were taken out putting all pedistrian traffic on the street and in harms way of vehicles.  This is especially true during the winter because snow banks block off all pedistrian routes expect for the middle of the street. Can we expect sidewalks to be re-installed the full length of 2nd and 3rd streets so pedistrians aren't forced to walk in the street?  Also, handicap accessiblitiy is virtually non-existent on the north ends of 2nd & 3rd streets due to the lack of sidewalks.  This wasn't good planning.

Sir - First, I really wish more people would get involved in these Electronic Town Halls.  It is an opportunity for everyone who can't make other meetings to communicate and have our ideas/concerns addressed.  (Or maybe I just take a stronger concern for the place I work) :).                 .......   My question:  While traveling to other Army installations, some of them allow the civilian employees to utilize the Commissary and PX with full access.  Fort Leavenworth was one when I was there a few years back.  I continually read about the very real concerns of Commissary's shutting down and decreased military use of the PX because they can't compete with the "big box" stores.  Is there a way, since our Commissary and PX are so small, to request an exception for RIA to allow our civilian staff to utilize them both? (I know the PX has limited access right now).  I would think allowing the civilian workforce access would easily increase sales, especially for the Commissary as employees would stop for groceries on their way home. As a military brat, prior spouse, and civilian employee I fully support the Commissary's and PX's, and the convenience of having them near where one works is a strong draw as potential customers.  If other military installations can authorize civilian use (with a CAC), can RIA follow suit?  It seems like a win win situation to me - increased sales for both stores, a large customer base right at their doorstep, and the civilians get the convenience of not having to drive to their local big box or grocery stores.  ...... Thank you for the opportunity to voice my request.

Thank you to everyone for your participation in our Installation Electronic Townhall. We look forward to the next townhall to be conducted quarterly, and for special events, as this one has been another success.

Good evening -- I am Col. Elmer Speights, Jr., commander of the U.S. Army Garrison, Rock Island Arsenal. Welcome to the Rock Island Arsenal's second Installation Electronic Town Hall. I am here with my staff to address your questions. We'll make every effort to answer, here and now, in real time. For more complex responses, or those requiring research, we may ask if we can find an answer and get back to you. We do ask that all questions concern the Arsenal and its operations, and that all participants conduct themselves as adults and good neighbors. Thanks for participating and being a good neighbor of Rock Island Arsenal. Let's begin.

A response to each question posted here for the town hall will have a response posted to it starting at 6 p.m. Wednesday, Jan. 14. Thank you in advance for posting your questions. For those who haven't posted yet, you can post anytime up and through the end of the town hall.

I come in on the Davenport side of the Island every morning and it is a mess.  The gate has been reduced down to one lane and when it is open - there is a back up on the bridge because of this (like this morning).  I was told  the building that was constructed was to protect the Guards from the winter elements, but it is closed every time the temperature drops below zero.  I would like to see a plan for  the people who use the Davenport gate that is  more secure and efficient than the plan in place today. Thank you.

Dang, hit return too soon... Here are the items I intended to post. 1. It's only Wednesday and the Rock Island gate has already been reduced to one lane twice during peak morning traffic... to top off the heater tanks! Both times created hazardous situations with motorists attempting to back out of the lane sudenly closed.... This solution is too easy: make it daily SOP to top off all the heater tanks at 0600, or whatever time precedes the main influx. Top them off again after the evening rush. In any case, have a plan, not just a reaction.  2. What benefits accrue from deploying the stop signs at the south end of Government Bridge when the Davenport Gate is closed? Th There is no cross traffic, so what's the point?  Seems to me it's a classic "we've always done it this way."  Time for a proper assessment.  3. How hard would it be to place an illuminated sign at on westbound Rodman Ave, just before Sylvan Drive near the PX, indicating whether the Davenport Gate is open or closed?  Looks to me like another example of "everybody knows the operating hours, so what's the problem?" How about people new to RIA, or those of who use the gate infrequently?  Serve the people, not the servants... 4. A large number of Bldg 350 employees use the E/W road one block north of and  paralleling Rodman Ave. (sorry, the map won't tell me the name) to approach the Bldg 350 parking lot... the road is in a terrible state and seems never to make it onto the list of repairs. From sheer volume, it warrants a fair look.  We're a great place; let's make it better.
I am concerned about the upcoming construction on the island for several reasons.

Issue 1: Allowing bike traffic to utilize the Moline Gate:
What can we do to make this possible? I was told there was a safety issue involved whether it was bikers in danger of falling off the bridge etc... If there is a safety issue involved can we build something whether it be a fence/barrier to make this happen? Having to spend an extra 45 minutes on a bicycle to get onto the post via the Rock Island gate hardly seems like the right answer. 

Issue 2: Modifying installation access procedures during inclement  weather:
I understand that the local crews do a good job of clearing the roads when it snows or when there's ice on the roads; however, the current inclement weather procedures and safety considerations do not line up with what the rest of the army's installations are doing worldwide. If the weather requires a late work call, please make that call and not put us Soldiers at risk of an accident. I have been on multiple installations over the last 10 years and can tell you the inclement weather procedures here are not conducive to a safe environment and do not line up with what other installations are doing.

Thank you to everyone for your participation in our inaugural Arsenal Island Electronic Townhall. For any questions that we are following up on we will be posting those responses in coming days. We look forward to the next townhall to be conducted quarterly, and for special events, as this one has been a success.

Good evening -- I am Col. Elmer Speight Jr., commander of the U.S. Army Garrison, Rock Island Arsenal. Welcome to the Rock Island Arsenal's first-ever Arsenal Island Electronic Townhall. I am here with my staff to address your questions. We'll make every effort to answer, here and now, in real time.  For more complex responses, or those requiring research, we may ask if we can find an answer and get back to you. We do ask that all questions concern the Arsenal and its operations, and that all participants conduct themselves as adults and good neighbors. Thanks for participating and being a good neighbor of Rock Island Arsenal. Let's begin.

A response to each of these questions will be posted during the townhall which starts at 6 p.m. Wednesday, May 7. Thank you for posting your questions. For those who haven't posted yet, you can post anytime up and through the end of the townhall.

Posted on behalf of a JMC employee:  I fully acknowledge the necessity of safely operating vehicles and observing the rules of the road on the installation.  Recent increased traffic enforcement activity has successfully driven that point home - as intended.  With that said, how do you justify the hiring of 13 additional police officers for the purpose of increased law enforcement actions on a decreasing pool of federal employees who are predominantly business hours-only visitors to this island?  Is there also a need for increased law enforcement actions toward the island residents or golf course patrons because of some increased criminal activity during all hours of the day/night and weekends?  A nearly 50% increase in permanent police officer positions seems inconsistent with decreased operating budgets for all AMC Commands (including IMCOM) coupled with a low threat Force Protection Condition (Alpha) environment.  What is the current ratio of RIA police officer to criminal offenses committed?  Is it currently indicative of understaffing compared to the local communities that surround RIA?  If so, I would contend that the island resident/workforce demographic is a highly law abiding cross-section of the general population that doesn't necessitate a further increase in police force presence to maintain law and order.
Is there a plan to improve roadways and parking lots around the island? Many large potholes, and deteriorating road surfaces.

The limited hours of operation at the Davenport gate are a major inconvenience, particularly for employees at the Corps of Engineers. It would not have been quite so bad if the old road that runs along the front of the Clock Tower hadn't closed (leading to the old Rock Island gate).  As it stands now  there is no way for Corps employees heading to Iowa to enter, or exit, the island without a considerable amount of backtracking. Is the closing of the Davenport gate, other than during "peak" hours a permananet situation? At the very least, the open hours of operation need to be expanded. Instead of having two guards standing in one guard shack at the Rock Island gate, which I have seen on several occassions, why can't one of those guards man the Davenport gate?

Why is there a posted speed limit of 10 MPH when passing pedestrians on the road?  Most Army bases require 10 MPH when passing formations but not a single runner.  25 MPH is a typical speed limit for residential neighborhoods where children are; therefore, wouldn't it be adequate when passing adult runners / walkers on the road?

Use of Headphones/Bluetooth on sidewalks ---  In Army regulations as well as the pertaining DoDI, a separate distinction is made between sidewalks and roadways. The Army Safety Program (AR 385-10, Section 6-5) states -- Using headphones or earphones while walking, jogging, skating, and bicycling, including pocket bike, motorcycle or moped on Army installation roads and streets, is prohibited.  None of the regulations, instructions, or policies I have located state that sidewalks are included, and all of them refer to a sidewalk as a separate entity than a roadway or street. The Garrison response to an inquiry April 2014 was that all sidewalks at RIA are included in the ban on earphone use on roadways and streets yet the RIA policy only says roadways/streets.  I understand where there is no sidewalk in certain areas - like along the river/golf course - one must walk on the roadway and thus earphones should not be used, but sidewalks are designated for pedestrian use only and corner crosswalks have either stop signs or lights.  Why are we not allowed to wear ear-buds for music while walking on sidewalks on RIA?  And since Bluetooth, smart phone ear pieces and wired phone ear buds are all considered headphones/earphones, do they also come under this policy and are we restricted from using our phones using these devices on sidewalks?

To get the designation, an honorably discharged veteran must present a copy of their DD 214 or applicable discharge document to their county Veterans Affairs office.

Here in the Quad Cities, in Scott County, it's the Commission of Veterans Affairs; their website is located at www.scottcountyiowa.com/community/veterans.php

That office will complete an Iowa DOT form and confirm the applicant’s veteran status, which authorizes the Iowa DOT to place the designation on the individual’s DL or nonoperator ID. The veteran must then take the completed form to any Iowa DL issuance location and request that the veteran designation be added to his or her DL or nonoperator ID card.

Veterans may expedite the process by bringing a completed application form with them to the county Veterans Affairs office, along with a copy of their DD 214. The form is available online at: https://va.iowa.gov/images/DOT432035.pdf

Christian hermits originally gathered at Mount Serbal, believing it to be the biblical Mount Sinai. However, in the 4th century, under the Byzantine Empire, the monastery built there was abandoned in favour of the newer belief that Mount Saint Catherine was the Biblical Mount Sinai; a new monastery - St. Catherine's Monastery was built at its foot, and the alleged site of the biblical burning bush was identified.  The bush growing at the spot (a bramble, scientific name Rubus sanctus,) was later transplanted several yards away to a courtyard of the monastery, and its original spot was covered by a chapel dedicated to the Annunciation, with a silver star marking where the roots of the bush had come out of the ground.  The Monks at St. Catherine's Monastery, following church tradition, believe that this bush is, in fact, the original bush seen by Moses, rather than a later replacement, and anyone entering the chapel is required to remove their shoes, just as Moses was in the biblical account.  However, in modern times, it is not Mount Saint Catherine, but the adjacent Jebel Musa, (Mount Moses,) which is currently identified as Mount Sinai by popular tradition and guide books; this identification arose from bedouin tradition.  Mount Serbal, Jebel Musa, and Mount Saint Catherine, all lie at the southern tip of the Sinai peninsula, but the peninsula's name is a comparatively modern invention, and it was not known by that name at the time of Josephus or earlier.  Most modern scholars, as well as many modern theologians, dismiss the idea that the biblical Sinai was at the south of the peninsula, instead favouring locations in the Hijaz, (at the north west of Saudi Arabia,) northern Arabah, (in the vicinity of Petra, or the surrounding area,) or occasionally in the central or northern Sinai Peninsula.  Hence, the majority of academics and theologians agree that if the burning bush ever existed, then it is highly unlikely to be the bush preserved at St Catherine's Monastery.

I was working for DFAS in bldg 68.  Someone had a small TV and we watched it happen.  After the towers and the Pentagon there was a rumor that the State Dept was also hit.  We were told we could make a quick phone call to family and then evacuate the Island.

I had dropped my son off at the CDC, arrived at the Clock Tower Bldg. and checked the Internet for that day's news. As soon as I read about a plane hitting the World Trade Center I freaked as my brother lived in Manhattan and had been doing some jobs in the World Trade Center. After talking w/ my brother, and knew he was safe in his apartment, our office started watching the TV coverage just moments after the second plane had hit the second tower. We were watching the NBC news coverage, which was apprehensive in connecting the planes with terrorism. Their coverage had switched to a telephone call to a reporter inside the Pentagon, I no more than commented that something could happen to the Pentagon and the reporter interrupted the interviewer and stated he felt the building shake and suspected a possible bomb. We watched the two towers fall during live coverage and it wasn't long before we were all told to go home that the installation was being evacuated. On the way out some of the employees who had been there for awhile were comparing the evacuation to how the Island reacted to the Oklahoma City bombing and what we could expect in regard to security.
Bldg. 102.  We turned CNN on in our training room and watched what was going on.

I remember like it was yesterday. At the time I worked at DFAS, bldg 68. I had seen the first plane hit on a small tv I had, then the second plane hit. I knew then there was something seriously wrong. We were evacuated a short time later. A very scary, sombering experience. My son is now in the Air Force, and to think he was only 12 on that date!

Congress gave final approval Wednesday to legislation that authorizes the Pentagon to spend nearly $160 billion... ✂ Congress considers the defense authorization bill to be its primary chance to sway Pentagon policy. While it does not transfer money into Defense Department coffers, it does serve as a blueprint for the defense appropriations bill by authorizing spending levels.

Both states that border the Rock Island Arsenal, Illinois and Iowa, are losing a congressional seat and an electoral vote. U.S. Census Bureau data released Dec. 21 showed Illinois' population grew a little more than 3 percent in the past decade, up to 12.8 million people. In Iowa, the population grew by 4.1 percent from 2000 to 2010 to just over 3 million people. But the slow growth in both states compared to other states was not enough to keep Illinois or Iowa from losing seats in Congress, as well as votes in the Electoral College. Illinois will be going from 19 congressional districts/seats to 18, and will decrease from 21 votes in the Electoral College to 20. In Iowa, the state will go from five congressional districts/seats to four, and electoral seats will drop from seven to six.
